item.title: RStudio vs. Python
item.description: My blog post #Using RStudio to index x <- "dog" x ## [1] "dog" #Using RStudio to create lists y <- list (1, 3, 5) #creating vector is only applicable to R print(y) ## [[1]] ## [1] 1 ## ## [[2]] ## [1] 3 ## ## [[3]] ## [1] 5 z <- list("a","b","c") print(z) ## [[1]] ## [1] "a" ## ## [[2]] ## [1] "b" ## ## [[3]] ## [1] "c" #Using RStudio to extract elements from lists y[1] #notice in R counting starts at 1 ## [[1]] ## [1] 1 z[3] ## [[1]] ## [1] "c" #Creating ranges in RStudio list <- c(1:5) list #notice the last element is 5.

item.title: Projects
item.description: Projects Here are some projects I have recently completed: Exploratory Data Analysis with Tidyverse Tools Modeling, Testing, and Classification

item.title: Project 1: Exploratory Data Analysis
item.description: For this project, I chose to observe different economic variables across all the US states. The first dataset “state” contains both unemployment and uninsured rates of individuals across all 50 states and District of Columbia. The second dataset “rent” covers the rent estimates and the income in dollar amount across the 50 states and District of Columbia. I acquired these datasets from my friend, who is an economics student at UT, because I was interested to observe whether there was any relationship between all the variables mentioned and which variables affected the states the most back in 2016.

item.title: Project 2: Modeling, Testing, and Predicting
item.description: #Packages library(tidyr); library(ggplot2); library(lmtest); library(dplyr); library(tidyverse) #Dataset #write.csv(USA_arrests,"USAarrests.csv") arrests <- read.csv("USAarrests.csv") #Tidying Data arrests <- arrests%>%select(-X) arrests ## State Murder UrbanPop Location Affiliation Unemployment Income ## 1 Alabama 13.2 58 0 0 5.8 47221 ## 2 Alaska 10.0 48 1 0 6.9 75723 ## 3 Arizona 8.1 80 1 0 5.4 57100 ## 4 Arkansas 8.8 50 0 0 4.0 45907 ## 5 California 9.0 91 1 1 5.5 66637 ## 6 Colorado 7.
